schema:description: The Minimum Information for a Genome Sequence (MIGS) standard as defined by Genomic Standards Consortium (v4). This template has been designed specifically for the Investigation type "Eukaryotic" .

Environment material.schema:description: The environmental material level refers to the material that was displaced by the sample, or material in which a sample was embedded, prior to the sampling event. Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water.
Environment material.description: Environment material field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Environment material.title: Environment material field schema
Environment material.schema:name: Environment material

Sequence name or Identifier.schema:description: The name of the species sequenced or its INSDC identifier could be used here to help distinguish which sequence is being described.
Sequence name or Identifier.description: Sequence name or Identifier field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Sequence name or Identifier.title: Sequence name or Identifier field schema
Sequence name or Identifier.schema:name: Sequence name or Identifier

longitude (geographic location).schema:description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
longitude (geographic location).description: longitude (geographic location) field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
longitude (geographic location).title: longitude (geographic location) field schema
longitude (geographic location).schema:name: longitude (geographic location)

Sequencing method.schema:description: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid
Sequencing method.description: Sequencing method field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Sequencing method.title: Sequencing method field schema
Sequencing method.schema:name: Sequencing method

Propogation.schema:description: This field is specific to different taxa. For phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice
Propogation.description: Propogation field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Propogation.title: Propogation field schema
Propogation.schema:name: Propogation

Isolation and growth conditions.schema:description: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material
Isolation and growth conditions.description: Isolation and growth conditions field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Isolation and growth conditions.title: Isolation and growth conditions field schema
Isolation and growth conditions.schema:name: Isolation and growth conditions

Number of replicons.schema:description: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote
Number of replicons.description: Number of replicons field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Number of replicons.title: Number of replicons field schema
Number of replicons.schema:name: Number of replicons

items.schema:description: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake.
items.description: Environment feature field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
items.title: Environment feature field schema
items.schema:name: Environment feature

latitude (geographic location).schema:description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
latitude (geographic location).description: latitude (geographic location) field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
latitude (geographic location).title: latitude (geographic location) field schema
latitude (geographic location).schema:name: latitude (geographic location)

ploidy.schema:description: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO
ploidy.description: ploidy field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
ploidy.title: ploidy field schema
ploidy.schema:name: ploidy

Environmental Package.schema:description: This template is specifically designed for MIGS only. MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported
Environmental Package.description: Environmental Package field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Environmental Package.title: Environmental Package field schema
Environmental Package.schema:name: Environmental Package

Collection date.schema:description: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
Collection date.description: Collection date field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Collection date.title: Collection date field schema
Collection date.schema:name: Collection date

Submitted to INSDC.schema:description: Please enter the accession of the sequence as provided by INSDC archives (NCBI, EBI or DDBJ), this can be a BioProject accession.
Submitted to INSDC.description: Submitted to INSDC field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Submitted to INSDC.title: Submitted to INSDC field schema
Submitted to INSDC.schema:name: Submitted to INSDC

geographic location (country and/or sea,.schema:description: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (v 1.512) (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
geographic location (country and/or sea,.description: geographic location (country and/or sea,region) field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
geographic location (country and/or sea,.title: geographic location (country and/or sea,region) field schema
geographic location (country and/or sea,.schema:name: geographic location (country and/or sea,region)

Assembly.schema:description: How was the assembly done (e.g. with a text based assembler like phrap or a flowgram assembler); estimated error rate associated with the finished sequences (e.g. error rate of 1 in 1000 bp); and the method of calculation
Assembly.description: Assembly field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Assembly.title: Assembly field schema
Assembly.schema:name: Assembly

items.schema:description: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO
items.description: Environment Biome field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
items.title: Environment Biome field schema
items.schema:name: Environment Biome

Project name.schema:description: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized
Project name.description: Project name field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Project name.title: Project name field schema
Project name.schema:name: Project name

Estimated size.schema:description: The estimated size of the genome prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period.
Estimated size.description: Estimated size field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Estimated size.title: Estimated size field schema
Estimated size.schema:name: Estimated size

Investigation type.schema:description: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIGS/MIMS compliant reports as standardized by Genomic Standards Consortium. This field is either eukaryote,bacteria,virus,plasmid,organelle, metagenome,mimarks-survey, or mimarks-specimen
Investigation type.description: Investigation type field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Investigation type.title: Investigation type field schema
Investigation type.schema:name: Investigation type

Finishing strategy.schema:description: Was the genome project intended to produce a complete or draft genome, Coverage, the fold coverage of the sequencing expressed as 2x, 3x, 18x  etc, and how many contigs were produced for the genome
Finishing strategy.description: Finishing strategy field schema generated by the CEDAR Template Editor 1.9.0
Finishing strategy.title: Finishing strategy field schema
Finishing strategy.schema:name: Finishing strategy

propertyDescriptions.Environment feature: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Compared to biome, feature is a descriptor of the more local environment. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake.
propertyDescriptions.latitude (geographic location): The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude and longitude. The values should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system
propertyDescriptions.ploidy: The ploidy level of the genome (e.g. allopolyploid, haploid, diploid, triploid, tetraploid). It has implications for the downstream study of duplicated gene and regions of the genomes (and perhaps for difficulties in assembly). For terms, please select terms listed under class ploidy (PATO:001374) of Phenotypic Quality Ontology (PATO), and for a browser of PATO (v 2013-10-28) please refer to http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/PATO

propertyDescriptions.Environmental Package: This template is specifically designed for MIGS only. MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. All environmental packages listed here are further defined in separate subtables. By giving the name of the environmental package, a selection of fields can be made from the subtables and can be reported
propertyDescriptions.Collection date: The time of sampling, either as an instance (single point in time) or interval. In case no exact time is available, the date/time can be right truncated i.e. all of these are valid times: 2008-01-23T19:23:10+00:00; 2008-01-23T19:23:10; 2008-01-23; 2008-01; 2008; Except: 2008-01; 2008 all are ISO8601 compliant
propertyDescriptions.Sequence name or Identifier: The name of the species sequenced or its INSDC identifier could be used here to help distinguish which sequence is being described.
propertyDescriptions.Submitted to INSDC: Please enter the accession of the sequence as provided by INSDC archives (NCBI, EBI or DDBJ), this can be a BioProject accession.
propertyDescriptions.geographic location (country and/or sea,: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name followed by specific region name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (v 1.512) (http://purl.bioontology.org/ontology/GAZ)
propertyDescriptions.Isolation and growth conditions: Publication reference in the form of pubmed ID (pmid), digital object identifier (doi) or url for isolation and growth condition specifications of the organism/material
propertyDescriptions.Project name: Name of the project within which the sequencing was organized
propertyDescriptions.Assembly: How was the assembly done (e.g. with a text based assembler like phrap or a flowgram assembler); estimated error rate associated with the finished sequences (e.g. error rate of 1 in 1000 bp); and the method of calculation
propertyDescriptions.Environment Biome: Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Biome should be treated as the descriptor of the broad ecological context of a sample. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO (v 2013-06-14) terms can be found via the link: www.environmentontology.org/Browse-EnvO
propertyDescriptions.Sequencing method: Sequencing method used; e.g. Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid
propertyDescriptions.Propogation: This field is specific to different taxa. For phages: lytic/lysogenic, for plasmids: incompatibility group (Note: there is the strong opinion to name phage propagation obligately lytic or temperate, therefore we also give this choice
propertyDescriptions.Estimated size: The estimated size of the genome prior to sequencing. Of particular importance in the sequencing of (eukaryotic) genome which could remain in draft form for a long or unspecified period.
propertyDescriptions.Investigation type: Nucleic Acid Sequence Report is the root element of all MIGS/MIMS compliant reports as standardized by Genomic Standards Consortium. This field is either eukaryote,bacteria,virus,plasmid,organelle, metagenome,mimarks-survey, or mimarks-specimen
propertyDescriptions.Finishing strategy: Was the genome project intended to produce a complete or draft genome, Coverage, the fold coverage of the sequencing expressed as 2x, 3x, 18x  etc, and how many contigs were produced for the genome
propertyDescriptions.Number of replicons: Reports the number of replicons in a nuclear genome of eukaryotes, in the genome of a bacterium or archaea or the number of segments in a segmented virus. Always applied to the haploid chromosome count of a eukaryote

Environmental material terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water.
